questions.question: In Unity, what is the primary purpose of a GameObject?
options: To write and execute C# scripts.
To act as a container for components.
To render graphics directly to the screen.
To store player data, like score and health.
questions.hint: Think about the hierarchical structure you see in the Unity Editor's Hierarchy window.

questions.question: Which C# class must a script inherit from to be attached to a GameObject in Unity?
questions.hint: This base class provides access to important game loop functions like Start(), Update(), and Awake().

questions.question: What is the main function of the 'Prefab' system in Unity?
options: To define the physics properties of an object.
questions.hint: Think about how you would efficiently create many copies of the same object, like enemies or bullets.

questions.question: Which component is essential for making a GameObject respond to physics forces?
questions.hint: This component adds properties like mass, drag, and gravity to an object.

questions.question: In the Unity Editor, which window is primarily used to view and edit the properties of a selected GameObject?
questions.hint: When you click on an object in your scene, its details appear in this window.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'Update' method in a MonoBehaviour script?
options: It's called once when the script instance is being loaded.
It's called every frame, if the script is enabled.
It's called when a physics simulation step is about to occur.
It's called only when the GameObject is first created.
questions.hint: This method is ideal for handling continuous game logic, like player input.

questions.question: Which Unity feature is used to create animations?
questions.hint: These two windows work together to create and manage animation clips and their transitions.

questions.question: What does the 'SerializeField' attribute do in a C# script?
options: It makes a public variable hidden in the Inspector.
It makes a private variable visible and editable in the Inspector.
It saves the variable's value to a file automatically.
It converts the variable to a string.
questions.hint: This is useful for keeping variables private in code while still allowing designers to adjust them in the editor.

questions.question: In Unity's UI system, what component is used to make a UI element clickable?
questions.hint: This component has an 'OnClick' event that you can configure to call a function when the element is clicked.

questions.question: What is the primary role of a 'Scene' in Unity?
options: A single level or area of your game.
A collection of all the assets in your project.
A container for all your C# scripts.
A file that stores player preferences.
questions.hint: Think of it as a container for all the GameObjects that make up a specific part of your game.

questions.question: Which method is used to instantiate a Prefab at runtime?
questions.hint: This is a static method of the 'Object' class.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'Start' method in a MonoBehaviour script?
options: It's called before the first frame update.
It's called when the script is enabled.
It's called when the application quits.
questions.hint: This is a good place to initialize variables.

questions.question: Which component is necessary for a GameObject to be visible in the game?
questions.hint: This component takes the geometry from the Mesh Filter and renders it.

questions.question: How do you get a reference to another component on the same GameObject in a script?
questions.hint: This method searches the current GameObject for a component of a specific type.

questions.question: What is the purpose of 'Time.deltaTime'?
options: The total time the game has been running.
The time it took to complete the last frame.
The time scale of the game.
questions.hint: This value is essential for making movement and other actions frame-rate independent.

questions.question: Which Unity window shows a hierarchical view of all GameObjects in the current Scene?
questions.hint: This window allows you to see the parent-child relationships between objects.

questions.question: What is the role of a 'Collider' component?
options: To define the physical shape of an object for collisions.
questions.hint: Without this, objects would pass through each other.

questions.question: Which of the following is a value type in C#?
questions.hint: These types are stored directly on the stack.

questions.question: What does the 'Awake' method do in a MonoBehaviour script?
options: It's called when the script instance is being loaded, before 'Start'.
It's called only when the script is disabled.
It's called every fixed framerate frame.
questions.hint: This method is always called before any 'Start' functions and after all objects are initialized.

questions.question: What is a 'Coroutine' in Unity?
options: A function that can pause execution and return control to Unity, then continue where it left off on a later frame.
A way to run code in parallel on multiple threads.
questions.hint: These are often used for creating sequences of actions over time.

questions.question: Which component is the main source of audio in a Unity scene?
questions.hint: This component plays back an Audio Clip in the scene.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the 'Project' window in the Unity Editor?
options: To view the hierarchy of GameObjects in the scene.
To display errors, warnings, and other messages from Unity.
To show and organize the asset files for your project.
To edit the properties of a selected asset.
questions.hint: This window mirrors the 'Assets' folder in your project directory.

questions.question: In C#, which keyword is used to declare a variable that cannot be changed after it's initialized?
questions.hint: This keyword is used for values that are constant at compile-time.

questions.question: What does 'transform.position' represent?
options: The rotation of the GameObject in world space.
The scale of the GameObject relative to its parent.
The position of the GameObject in world space.
The local position of the GameObject relative to its parent.
questions.hint: This property is a Vector3 that holds the x, y, and z coordinates of the GameObject.

questions.question: Which of these is NOT a primitive data type in C#?
questions.hint: This type is actually a reference type, a sequence of characters.
